posts.name: Zack
posts.cooked: My team has been using a 4-pin LED strip, but I just realized it doesn’t plug directly into the Roborio. We are using an Orange Pi 5 running PhotonVision and were hoping to also use it to control the LEDs. Is it possible to do both things simultaneously?

link_counts.title: 12V Individually Addressable LED Light Strip 16.4 ft - AndyMark, Inc

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Extremely important note: Do not output anything besides the cleaned paragraph. Only the cleaned version should be provided.

Those LEDs can be controlled directly from the RIO, making it the simplest method. Here’s how:

LED strips have been widely used by teams for several reasons. They allow teams to debug robot functionality from the audience, serve as a visual indicator for their robot, and...

The key is to power them using a 12V supply, such as through a PDH port on the RIO, while utilizing its PWM signal pins. This results in some unconventional wiring setups. However, the Orange Pi/PhotonVision cannot power these LEDs directly, though you can still send signals to them, though this process is significantly more complex than using the RIO.

link_counts.title: Addressable LEDs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: You end up with a bit of odd wiring. No more odd than powering a long 5V strip since the roboRIO can’t handle that load either, and it's even less odd than our need for a 12V to 5V converter, which the operator wouldn't have to use.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: It’s odd because there isn’t a single, well-defined connection point for it, unlike most other FIRST Robotics Competition wiring, which typically has precisely color-coded, 1:1 connections and clear wiring guides. This isn’t always the case with LED strips, though—they usually require optional third-party solutions for proper connectivity.

posts.name: Zack
posts.cooked: Thank you for your message. The LED strip’s plug has four wires connected together with plastic, making it impossible to insert it directly into the PWM port. Would I need to separate the wires and recreate the connector?

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: Oh man, Andymark’s documentation for these sucks. This should help: The 12V power and ground go to the PDH or other 12V power source. You’d preferably want to use a more stable 12V power source than the PDH, but I’m not sure what you have available, and this will get you moving. The DI goes to the Rio’s PWM signal pin (any one is fine, you select it in code for the AddressableLED class). The BI pin is “backup input,” which is used to jump the signal past broken LEDs. This gets the same input as the DI, so just connect BI and DI together. This can be done with a solder blob, a jumper wire, or splice in your wire (whatever is easier).

posts.name: Zack
posts.cooked: Extremely, I’ll try this next week!

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: @tekdemo demonstrates the proper connections to ensure everything works correctly. Pay attention to the LED strip's directionality. Be cautious as you're performing delicate surgery on the arrow's tip, specifically near where the strip begins with BI, DI. If there's a connector on the arrow's head end, it's meant for attaching additional strips.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: To avoid damaging the joint when soldering LEDs, take care to handle the process carefully. However, even if you accidentally damage the nearest LED, the circuit should remain functional due to the presence of a backup pin. In the worst-case scenario, simply remove the faulty LED and attempt the repair again. This approach ensures strips are relatively easy to fix.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: That often happened with my team—it’s not a rare case with beginner soldering students. Don’t cut the strip to the desired final length until you’ve confirmed it works with the new connectors. However, the worst-case scenario is when the strip is a bit too short, but no one notices—and you can always extend it once you understand how it works.
